nodes.text: The impacts of retirement savings policies on total wealth accumulation depend on whether they change savings via active choice (price subsidies) or passive choice (automatic contributions), with automatic contributions expected to increase total saving more than subsidies

Conceptual two-type model: population is mixture of active savers (optimize, respond to price subsidies and reoptimize) and passive savers (set pension contributions exogenously and respond only to automatic contributions or income changes); comparative statics predict (a) automatic contributions raise retirement contributions for passive savers but not for active savers, (b) price subsidies change active savers contributions but not passive savers, and (c) automatic contributions may or may not raise total saving depending on whether passive savers reduce consumption or liquid savings

Data and empirical strategy: administrative panel for Denmark 1995-2009 with 41 million person-year observations, third-party reported flows into retirement accounts and taxable account balances; quasi-experimental designs: firm-switch event studies for employer pensions, regression discontinuity for 1998 MSP, and difference-in-differences around 1999 top-bracket subsidy change

Empirical identification choices: measure total saving as pension contributions plus change in taxable balances (pre-tax), scale variables to income, account for corners (zero contributions) via threshold/interior estimators and sample restrictions, cluster inference by income bins or firms as appropriate

Employer automatic contributions: when workers switch to firms that increase employer pension contributions by DKr 1, total pension contributions increase by about 0.95 DKr and total saving increases by about 0.78 DKr (holding total compensation fixed), implying large pass-through of automatic employer contributions to total saving

Government Mandated Savings Plan (MSP): RD at income eligibility shows mandated 1% contribution raised total pension contributions with pass-through near 0.84-1.02 and raised total saving, i.e. mandated automatic contributions causally increase total saving for those affected

1999 capital-pension subsidy change (top-bracket reduction): diﬀerence-in-differences shows individual capital pension contributions fell sharply for top-bracket individuals (about DKr 2,449 lower on average for treated group), with marginal propensity to save in capital pensions falling ~0.021 per DKr of income

Heterogeneity and active vs. passive estimates: evidence from multiple designs implies two types with majority passive — approx. 15% active savers and ~85% passive savers (estimated b_alpha around 5-15% depending on design) — active savers are older, wealthier, more financially sophisticated and more likely to reoptimize

Mechanisms explaining diﬀerential eﬀects: (1) subsidies induce relatively few individuals to respond (most are passive), (2) responders mostly shift savings across accounts generating substantial crowd-out, especially within retirement accounts, (3) subsidies do not increase savings of passive individuals who are least prepared for retirement

Crowd-out estimates: within retirement accounts, about 0.47–0.57 DKr of each DKr reduced in capital pensions shifted into annuity pensions (partial substitution); crowd-out from retirement to taxable accounts is large — trimmed and threshold IV estimates imply roughly 0.98–1.0 DKr of each DKr moved into taxable saving (i.e., ~99% crowd-out by one measure) with 95% CI allowing substantial but not zero net new saving

Long-run wealth impacts of automatic contributions: employer-driven increases in pension contributions persist for at least ten years and lead to substantially higher retirement wealth balances (example: a 5% higher employer contribution at switch associated with ~25% of annual income more accrued wealth by age 60 for switchers)

Main conclusion and policy implication: automatic contributions (mandates, employer defaults) are more effective than price subsidies at increasing total saving per unit of public expenditure because subsidies largely transfer infra-marginal rents and generate high crowd-out while automatic contributions change behavior of passive savers and raise long-run wealth; therefore policies like automatic enrollment are more cost-effective for raising savings rates

Limitation and uncertainty: estimates of crowd-out in taxable saving are noisy because taxable saving levels vary substantially across years and designs based on level comparisons have low power; many results depend on Danish institutions and further research in other countries (e.g., US) and welfare analysis of policies is needed
